title: Bringing the Ark
shortSummary: In 1 Chronicles 13, King David organizes the gathering of Israel to bring the Ark of the Covenant back to Jerusalem, demonstrating his desire to honor God. However, the chapter also highlights the seriousness of God's holiness when Uzza is struck down for improperly handling the Ark, teaching the importance of reverence and obedience.
timeline: c. 1010 BC - Early reign of King David

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The king of Israel who initiates the plan to bring the Ark of God to Jerusalem, showing leadership and devotion.

keyCharacters.name: Uzza
keyCharacters.description: One of the men who drove the cart carrying the Ark; he is struck down by God for touching the Ark unlawfully.

keyCharacters.name: Ahio
keyCharacters.description: Brother of Uzza who helped drive the cart transporting the Ark from Kirjathjearim.

keyCharacters.name: Obededom the Gittite
keyCharacters.description: The man whose house temporarily houses the Ark after the incident with Uzza, and who receives God's blessing.

definitions.definition: The sacred chest that held the tablets of the Law, symbolizing God's presence among His people.
Heavenly beings depicted on the Ark's cover, representing God's throne and presence.
A flat area where grain was separated from chaff; here it is the place where Uzza touched the Ark.
The place named 'the breach of Uzza' where God struck Uzza for touching the Ark unlawfully.

outline.heading: David’s Proposal to Bring the Ark
outline.description: David consults with Israel’s leaders and the congregation to bring the Ark back to Jerusalem, emphasizing unity and seeking God's approval.

outline.heading: The Ark is Transported with Celebration
outline.description: The Ark is taken from Kirjathjearim on a new cart with music and rejoicing, reflecting worship and joy in God's presence.

outline.heading: Uzza’s Death and God’s Judgment
outline.description: Uzza touches the Ark to steady it and is struck dead by God, underscoring the holiness of God and the need for obedience to His commands.

outline.heading: David’s Fear and the Ark’s Temporary Rest
outline.description: David is afraid and delays bringing the Ark into the city, leaving it in Obededom’s house where God blesses the household, showing God’s favor despite human failure.

application: Seek God’s guidance and approval in all major decisions, just as David consulted leaders and sought the Lord’s will.
Approach God’s presence with reverence and obedience, recognizing His holiness and authority.
Learn from mistakes and respond with humility and faith, as David did after Uzza’s death.
Trust in God’s blessings even when plans do not go as expected, as seen in the blessing on Obededom’s household.

keyVerses.text: And let us bring again the ark of our God to us: for we enquired not at it in the days of Saul.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the importance of seeking God’s guidance and honoring Him properly.

keyVerses.text: And the anger of the LORD was kindled against Uzza, and he smote him, because he put his hand to the ark: and there he died before God.
keyVerses.significance: A solemn reminder of God’s holiness and the consequences of disobedience.

keyVerses.text: And the ark of God remained with the family of Obededom in his house three months. And the LORD blessed the house of Obededom, and all that he had.
keyVerses.significance: Demonstrates God’s blessing and presence even in unexpected circumstances.
